newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Washington Post front - July 31.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Washington Post front - July 31.

text.p: The Washington Post included the following stories on its front page on July 31:

WASHINGTON - The White House and congressional leaders agreed on a far-reaching plan that would strip Mayor Marion Barry and other officials of considerable power and put the D.C. financial control board in charge of most of the city government for at least four years.
WASHINGTON - Congress and the president may have shorn Mayor Marion Barry of his greatest powers and left the home rule aspirations of the nation's capital on something akin to life support.
JERUSALEM - Two synchronized suicide bombs killed at least 15 people and halted the first slight headway in the broken-down dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians.
WASHINGTON - Explorer Robert Ballard showed reporters photographs of what he described as the largest concentration of ancient shipwrecks ever found in the deep sea.

WASHINGTON - A Saudi who had agreed to provide information to FBI agents investigation last summer's fatal bombing of a U.S. military housing complex in Saudi Arabia has decided not to cooperate because he says he has no information about the case.

WASHINGTON - Sen. Fred Thompson, a Tennessee Republican, denounced the White House for stalling the Senate's investigation into campaign finance abuses and said his committee will subpoena the administration for all outstanding documents relative to its inquiry.
WASHINGTON - The commander of the Russian space station Mir said that his actions during last month's collision with a cargo ship averted a more serious catastrophe.
